comparison.difference: /ɪ/ is shorter and more relaxed, while /iː/ is longer and more tense.

description.describe:
The /ɪ/ sound is a short vowel, pronounced with:

  • Tongue position: Front, slightly raised but not as high as /iː/.
  • Jaw opening: Slightly open, not too wide.
  • Lip shape: Relaxed, slightly open, not rounded.
  • Tongue tension: Relaxed.
  • Duration: Short, not prolonged.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Keep your mouth slightly open, without tensing your lips.
  2. Position your tongue towards the front and slightly raised.
  3. Pronounce the sound quickly and shortly, avoiding lengthening it like /iː/.
  4. Compare it with the /iː/ sound by practicing word pairs like bit - beat.

comparison.difference: /ʊ/ is shorter and more relaxed, while /uː/ is longer and more tense.

description.describe:
The /ʊ/ sound is a short vowel, pronounced with:

  • Tongue position: High but slightly lower than /uː/.
  • Jaw opening: Slightly open.
  • Lip shape: Rounded but less than in /uː/.
  • Tongue tension: Relaxed.
  • Duration: Short, not prolonged.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Keep your lips slightly rounded.
  2. Position your tongue high, but not as high as for /uː/.
  3. Pronounce the sound quickly and shortly, avoiding lengthening it like /uː/.
  4. Compare it with the /uː/ sound by practicing word pairs like pull - pool.

comparison.difference: /ɛ/ is a short, relaxed vowel, while /eɪ/ is a diphthong that glides from /ɛ/ to /ɪ/.

description.describe:
The /ɛ/ sound is a short vowel, pronounced with:

  • Tongue position: Front, mid-low.
  • Jaw opening: Medium open.
  • Lip shape: Relaxed, not rounded.
  • Tongue tension: Relaxed.
  • Duration: Short, not prolonged.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Keep your mouth slightly open, with relaxed lips.
  2. Position your tongue in the middle of the mouth, slightly raised at the front.
  3. Pronounce the sound quickly and shortly, avoiding lengthening it into /eɪ/.
  4. Compare it with the /eɪ/ sound by practicing word pairs like bed - bait.

description.describe:
The /æ/ sound is a short vowel, pronounced with:

  • Tongue position: Front, low, with the jaw open wide.

comparison.difference: /ʌ/ is shorter and more central, while /ɑː/ is longer and more open.

description.describe:
The /ʌ/ sound is a short vowel, pronounced with:

  • Tongue position: Central, slightly raised but lower than /ɪ/.
  • Jaw opening: Moderately open.
  • Lip shape: Neutral, slightly relaxed.
  • Tongue tension: More relaxed than /ɪ/.
  • Duration: Short, but slightly longer than /ɪ/.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Open your mouth slightly and relax your tongue.
  2. Position your tongue in the middle of the mouth.
  3. Compare it with the /ɪ/ sound by practicing word pairs like cup - kip.

comparison.difference: /ə/ is always unstressed, while /ʌ/ can be stressed. /ə/ is the most common vowel sound in English.

description.describe:
The /ə/ sound (schwa) is the most common vowel sound in English, pronounced with:

  • Tongue position: Central, relaxed.
  • Jaw opening: Slightly open.
  • Lip shape: Neutral.
  • Tongue tension: Relaxed.
  • Duration: Very short.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Relax your mouth and tongue.
  2. Do not stress the syllable containing /ə/.
  3. Compare it with a stressed vowel by practicing word pairs like sofa - cup.

description.describe:
The /iː/ sound is a long vowel, pronounced with:

  • Tongue position: Front, high, and tense.
  • Jaw opening: Slightly open.
  • Lip shape: Unrounded and slightly spread.
  • Tongue tension: Tense.
  • Duration: Long and held.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Keep your tongue high and forward in the mouth.
  2. Stretch your lips slightly into a smile.
  3. Hold the sound longer than /ɪ/.
  4. Compare it with the /ɪ/ sound by practicing word pairs like sheep - ship.

comparison.difference: /ɜː/ is a longer, stressed vowel, while /ə/ (schwa) is shorter and always unstressed.

description.describe:
The /ɜː/ sound is a long vowel, pronounced with:

  • Tongue position: Mid-central and tense.
  • Jaw opening: Slightly open.
  • Lip shape: Neutral, not rounded.
  • Tongue tension: Tense.
  • Duration: Long and held.

  1. Keep your tongue in the center of your mouth.

description.describe:
The /ɔː/ sound is a long vowel, pronounced with:

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Keep your tongue in the back of your mouth, slightly low.

comparison.difference: /ɑː/ is longer and produced with a more open mouth, while /æ/ is shorter and more fronted.

description.describe:
The /ɑː/ sound is a long vowel, pronounced with:

  • Tongue position: Back, low, and tense.

comparison.difference: /eɪ/ is a diphthong that glides from /e/ to /ɪ/, while /ɛ/ is a short, monophthong sound.

description.describe:
The /eɪ/ sound is a diphthong, pronounced with:

  • Tongue position: Starts in the mid-front position (/e/), then moves up slightly towards /ɪ/.
  • Jaw opening: Slightly open, then closes slightly.
  • Lip shape: Relaxed and slightly spread.
  • Tongue tension: Moves from relaxed to slightly tenser.
  • Duration: Long, as it glides from one position to another.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Start with your tongue in a mid-front position (/e/).
  2. Move your tongue slightly up and towards the front (/ɪ/).
  3. Do not separate the two sounds; glide smoothly between them.
  4. Compare it with /ɛ/ by practicing word pairs like late - let.

  • Tongue tension: Moves from relaxed to slightly tenser.

description.describe:
The /aʊ/ sound is a diphthong, pronounced with:

  • Tongue position: Starts in a low, front position (/a/), then moves up to a high-back rounded position (/ʊ/).

  • Tongue tension: Moves from relaxed to slightly tenser.
  • Duration: Long, as it glides from one position to another.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Start with your tongue in a low-front position.
  2. Move your tongue up towards the high-back position.
  3. Round your lips slightly at the end of the sound.
  4. Compare it with /æ/ by practicing word pairs like now - nap.

comparison.difference: /ɪə/ is a diphthong that glides from /ɪ/ to /ə/, while /ɪ/ is a short monophthong sound.

description.describe:
The /ɪə/ sound is a diphthong, pronounced with:

  • Tongue position: Starts in a high-front position (/ɪ/), then moves to a mid-central position (/ə/).
  • Jaw opening: Starts slightly open and relaxes.
  • Lip shape: Neutral.
  • Tongue tension: Moves from tense to more relaxed.
  • Duration: Long, as it glides from one position to another.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Start with your tongue high and near the front of your mouth.
  2. Move your tongue down slightly towards the center.
  3. Glide smoothly between the two sounds.
  4. Compare it with /ɪ/ by practicing word pairs like here - hit.

comparison.difference: /eə/ is a diphthong that glides from /e/ to /ə/, while /e/ is a short, monophthong sound.

description.describe:
The /eə/ sound is a diphthong, pronounced with:

  • Tongue position: Starts in a mid-front position (/e/), then moves to a mid-central position (/ə/).
  • Jaw opening: Starts slightly open and then relaxes.
  • Lip shape: Neutral.
  • Tongue tension: Moves from slightly tense to more relaxed.
  • Duration: Long, as it glides from one position to another.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Start with your tongue in a mid-front position.
  2. Move your tongue slightly back towards the center.
  3. Glide smoothly between the two sounds.
  4. Compare it with /e/ by practicing word pairs like air - egg.

comparison.difference: /ʊə/ is a diphthong that glides from /ʊ/ to /ə/, while /ʊ/ is a short, monophthong sound.

description.describe:
The /ʊə/ sound is a diphthong, pronounced with:

  • Tongue position: Starts in a high-back position (/ʊ/), then moves to a mid-central position (/ə/).
  • Jaw opening: Starts slightly open and relaxes.
  • Lip shape: Starts rounded and moves to neutral.
  • Tongue tension: Moves from slightly tense to more relaxed.
  • Duration: Long, as it glides from one position to another.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Start with your tongue high and back in your mouth.
  2. Move your tongue slightly forward towards the center.
  3. Round your lips slightly at the beginning, then relax them.
  4. Compare it with /ʊ/ by practicing word pairs like tour - took.

comparison.difference: /f/ is voiceless (no vocal cord vibration), while /v/ is voiced (with vocal cord vibration).

description.describe:
The /f/ sound is a voiceless labiodental fricative, pronounced with:

  • Lips and teeth: Lower lip touches the upper teeth.
  • Airflow: Continuous air passes through the small gap between the lip and teeth.
  • Vocal cords: Do not vibrate.
  • Duration: Can be prolonged.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Place your lower lip against your upper teeth.
  2. Blow air through the small gap.
  3. Do not use your voice (compare with /v/ by feeling your throat).
  4. Practice minimal pairs like fan - van.

comparison.difference: /v/ is voiced (with vocal cord vibration), while /f/ is voiceless (without vocal cord vibration).

description.describe:
The /v/ sound is a voiced labiodental fricative, pronounced with:

  • Lips and teeth: Lower lip touches the upper teeth.
  • Airflow: Continuous air passes through the small gap between the lip and teeth.
  • Vocal cords: Vibrate.
  • Duration: Can be prolonged.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Place your lower lip against your upper teeth.
  2. Blow air through the small gap while using your voice.
  3. Compare it with /f/ by feeling your throat vibrate.
  4. Practice minimal pairs like fan - van.

comparison.difference: /θ/ is voiceless, whereas /ð/ is voiced.

description.describe:
The /θ/ sound is a voiceless fricative, pronounced with:

  • Airflow: Continuous airflow through a narrow constriction formed by the tongue and upper front teeth.
  • Tongue position: The tip of the tongue is placed against the upper front teeth without blocking the airflow completely.
  • Vocal cords: Do not vibrate when producing the sound.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Place the tip of your tongue lightly against the upper front teeth.
  2. Allow air to flow continuously between the tongue and teeth.
  3. Ensure your vocal cords remain relaxed and do not vibrate.

comparison.difference: /ð/ is voiced (vocal cords vibrate), while /θ/ is voiceless (no vocal cord vibration).

description.describe:
The /ð/ sound is a voiced dental fricative, pronounced with:

  • Tongue position: Tip of the tongue lightly touches the upper front teeth.
  • Airflow: Continuous air passes through the small gap between the tongue and teeth.
  • Vocal cords: Vibrate.
  • Duration: Can be prolonged.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Place the tip of your tongue against your upper front teeth.
  2. Blow air through the small gap while vibrating your vocal cords.
  3. Compare it with /θ/ by feeling your throat (if you feel vibration, it's /ð/; if not, it's /θ/).
  4. Practice minimal pairs like this - think.

comparison.difference: /s/ is voiceless (no vocal cord vibration), while /z/ is voiced (vocal cords vibrate).

description.describe:
The /s/ sound is a voiceless alveolar fricative, pronounced with:

  • Tongue position: Tip of the tongue is close to the alveolar ridge.
  • Airflow: Continuous air passes through a narrow gap, creating friction.
  • Vocal cords: Do not vibrate.
  • Duration: Can be prolonged.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Place the tip of your tongue near the alveolar ridge, but do not touch it.
  2. Blow air through the small gap while keeping your vocal cords silent.
  3. Compare it with /z/ by feeling your throat (if you feel vibration, it's /z/; if not, it's /s/).
  4. Practice minimal pairs like sip - zip.

comparison.difference: /z/ is voiced, meaning the vocal cords vibrate, while /s/ is voiceless.

description.describe:
The /z/ sound is a voiced consonant, pronounced with:

  • Vocal cord vibration: Unlike /s/, the vocal cords vibrate when pronouncing /z/.
  • Tongue position: The tip of the tongue is close to the alveolar ridge.
  • Airflow: Continuous, allowing air to pass through the narrow gap.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Place your tongue close to the alveolar ridge.
  2. Let air flow continuously while making your vocal cords vibrate.
  3. Contrast it with /s/ by practicing word pairs like sip - zip.

description.describe:
The /ʃ/ sound is a voiceless fricative, pronounced with:

  • Tongue position: The tongue is positioned near the roof of the mouth, slightly behind the alveolar ridge.
  • Airflow: Continuous friction sound produced by directing air over the tongue.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Position your tongue near the roof of your mouth.
  2. Let air pass through continuously without using your vocal cords.
  3. Compare it with /ʒ/ by practicing word pairs like she - genre.

comparison.difference: /h/ is a voiceless glottal fricative, whereas /x/ is a velar fricative.

description.describe:
The /h/ sound is a voiceless fricative, pronounced with:

  • Airflow: A smooth flow of air through the open glottis.
  • Tongue position: The tongue remains in a neutral position, depending on the following vowel.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Keep the vocal cords open, allowing air to pass freely.
  2. Maintain a neutral tongue position.
  3. Compare it with voiced sounds to feel the lack of vibration.

comparison.difference: /p/ is a voiceless bilabial plosive, whereas /b/ is voiced, and /f/ is a fricative.

description.describe:
The /p/ sound is a voiceless plosive, pronounced with:

  • Airflow: A brief stop of airflow by closing the lips, followed by a burst of air.
  • Lip position: The lips are fully closed before releasing the sound.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Close your lips completely.
  2. Build up air pressure behind your lips.
  3. Release the air quickly to produce the /p/ sound.

comparison.difference: /t/ is a voiceless alveolar plosive, whereas /d/ is voiced, and /θ/ is a voiceless dental fricative.

description.describe:
The /t/ sound is a voiceless plosive, pronounced with:

  • Airflow: A brief stop of airflow by placing the tongue against the alveolar ridge (the bumpy area just behind the upper front teeth), followed by a release of air.
  • Tongue position: The tip of the tongue touches the alveolar ridge, blocking the airflow, then quickly releases.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Place the tip of your tongue against the alveolar ridge, just behind your upper front teeth.
  2. Build up air pressure behind your tongue.

description.describe:
The /k/ sound is a voiceless plosive, pronounced with:

  • Vocal cords: Do not vibrate when producing the sound.

Pronunciation guide:

description.describe:
The /m/ sound is a voiced nasal consonant, pronounced with:

  • Vocal cords: Vibrate when producing the sound.

comparison.difference: /n/ is a voiced alveolar nasal, whereas /m/ is a voiced bilabial nasal, and /ŋ/ is a voiced velar nasal.

description.describe:
The /n/ sound is a voiced alveolar nasal consonant, produced by:

  • Airflow: Directing the airflow through the nasal cavity while blocking it in the oral cavity.
  • Tongue position: Placing the tip of the tongue against the alveolar ridge, just behind the upper front teeth, effectively stopping the airflow in the mouth.
  • Vocal cords: Vibrating during the production of the sound.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Place the tip of your tongue against the alveolar ridge, just behind your upper front teeth.
  2. Lower your soft palate to allow air to pass through your nose.
  3. Vibrate your vocal cords as you produce the sound.

comparison.difference: /ŋ/ is a voiced velar nasal, whereas /n/ is a voiced alveolar nasal, and /m/ is a voiced bilabial nasal.

description.describe:
The /ŋ/ sound is a voiced nasal consonant, pronounced with:

  • Airflow: Air passes through the nasal cavity as the back of the tongue contacts the velum (soft part of the roof of the mouth).
  • Tongue position: The back of the tongue presses against the velum, blocking airflow through the mouth.
  • Vocal cords: Vibrate during the production of the sound.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Raise the back of your tongue to touch the velum.
  2. Allow air to pass through your nose while keeping your vocal cords vibrating.
  3. Release the tongue from the velum to complete the sound.

comparison.difference: /j/ is a voiced palatal approximant, whereas /i/ is a close front unrounded vowel, and /ʒ/ is a voiced postalveolar fricative.

description.describe:
The /j/ sound is a voiced palatal approximant, pronounced with:

  • Airflow: Unrestricted airflow as the tongue approaches the hard palate without creating friction.
  • Tongue position: The middle of the tongue raises towards the hard palate.
  • Lip position: Generally neutral or slightly spread.
  • Vocal cords: Vibrate during the articulation.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Raise the middle part of your tongue towards the hard palate without touching it.
  2. Allow the air to flow freely over the tongue without creating friction.
  3. Ensure your vocal cords are vibrating as you produce the sound.

comparison.difference: /r/ is a voiced alveolar approximant, whereas /l/ is a voiced alveolar lateral approximant, and /w/ is a voiced labio-velar approximant.

description.describe:
The /r/ sound is a voiced alveolar approximant, pronounced with:

  • Airflow: Continuous airflow without friction.
  • Tongue position: The tip of the tongue is raised towards the alveolar ridge without touching it, creating a narrow space for the air to flow through.
  • Lip position: Often slightly rounded.
  • Vocal cords: Vibrate when producing the sound.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Raise the tip of your tongue towards the alveolar ridge, just behind your upper front teeth, without making contact.
  2. Keep your lips slightly rounded.
  3. Allow the air to flow continuously while vibrating your vocal cords.

comparison.difference: /l/ is a voiced alveolar lateral approximant, whereas /r/ is a voiced alveolar approximant.

description.describe:
The /l/ sound is a voiced alveolar lateral approximant, pronounced with:

  • Airflow: The airstream flows around the sides of the tongue.
  • Tongue position: The tip of the tongue touches the alveolar ridge, just behind the upper front teeth.
  • Vocal cords: Vibrate during the articulation.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Place the tip of your tongue against the alveolar ridge.
  2. Allow the airstream to flow around the sides of your tongue.
  3. Engage your vocal cords to produce the sound.

comparison.difference: /tʃ/ is an affricate combining the stop /t/ and the fricative /ʃ/, whereas /t/ is a voiceless alveolar plosive and /ʃ/ is a voiceless postalveolar fricative.

description.describe:
The /tʃ/ sound is a voiceless affricate, pronounced with:

  • Airflow: A brief stop of airflow by placing the tongue against the alveolar ridge, followed by a release into a fricative sound.
  • Tongue position: The tip of the tongue touches the alveolar ridge, then moves slightly back to allow the fricative release.
  • Vocal cords: Do not vibrate when producing the sound.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Place the tip of your tongue against the alveolar ridge, just behind your upper front teeth.
  2. Build up air pressure behind your tongue.
  3. Release the air by moving your tongue slightly back, creating a fricative sound without vibrating your vocal cords.

comparison.difference: /dʒ/ is voiced, whereas /tʃ/ is voiceless. /dʒ/ starts with a stop sound /d/ followed by the fricative /ʒ/.

description.describe:
The /dʒ/ sound is a voiced postalveolar affricate, produced by:

  • Airflow: Initially stopping the airflow by placing the tongue against the alveolar ridge, then releasing it to create friction in the postalveolar region.
  • Tongue position: The tip of the tongue touches the alveolar ridge, then moves slightly back to the postalveolar area upon release.
  • Vocal cords: Vibrate during the production of the sound.

Pronunciation guide:

  1. Place the tip of your tongue against the alveolar ridge, just behind your upper front teeth.
  2. Build up air pressure behind your tongue.
  3. Release the air while moving the tongue slightly back, creating friction, and ensure your vocal cords vibrate.
